results.headline: For the Joy of Worship, However Arduous
results.summary_short: Pan Nalin’s documentary “Faith Connections” examines the annual Kumbh Mela festival, which draws millions of Hindu pilgrims to a town in northern India.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Faith Connections

results.headline: Lonely Sea Mammal Seeks Tank Mate
results.summary_short: “Dolphin Tale 2” is the story of the humans who love one brave dolphin and the race to find a new playmate for her, because otherwise they’ll lose her to another aquarium.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dolphin Tale 2

results.headline: Sucked Into a Sinister Maw
results.summary_short: In “At the Devil’s Door,” nothing good comes of selling your soul, especially when Satan is involved.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of At the Devil's Door

results.headline: A Weakness for Cops, a Crime to Solve
results.summary_short: In “Archaeology of a Woman,” Sally Kirkland plays an ex-newspaper columnist battling dementia while a murder mystery unfolds.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Archaeology of a Woman

results.headline: Making Do With Little, Yet Making Art
results.summary_short: “Alumbrones,” a documentary by Bruce Donnelly, focuses on Cuban artists whose creative lives have been defined by scarcity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alumbrones

results.headline: From Money, but So Much More Than That
results.summary_short: “Altina” tracks the life of a tobacco heiress, artist and inventor who refused to be hemmed in by convention.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Altina

results.headline: An Apartment in the Marais, With Complications and Family Secrets
results.summary_short: In “My Old Lady,” a failed American playwright inherits a splendid Paris apartment, but French law gives his tenant the upper hand.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Old Lady

results.display_title: Born To Fly: Elizabeth Streb vs Gravity
results.headline: A Pursuit That Leaps, Crashes and Swings
results.summary_short: The documentary “Born to Fly: Elizabeth Streb vs. Gravity” uses performance and rehearsal footage to help profile this choreographer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Born To Fly: Elizabeth Streb vs Gravity

results.headline: Trying to Figure Out Her Patients and Herself
results.summary_short: “Once Upon a Time, Verônica” is a drama about a psychiatrist adjusting to professional and personal challenges in Recife, Brazil.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Once Upon a Time Veronica

results.headline: A Lightning Rod in a Game With Bats
results.summary_short: “No No: A Dockumentary” looks at the career of Dock Ellis, a pitcher with the Pittsburgh Pirates.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No No: A Dockumentary

results.headline: Intimate Feelings, Especially for Herself
results.summary_short: In “Wetlands,” a teenager with no bodily inhibitions hopes to reconcile her divorced parents.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Feuchtgebiete

results.headline: At This School, ‘B’ Is for Blood
results.summary_short: In “Innocence,” the new girl at school encounters a bloodsucking culture.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Innocence

results.headline: An Elvis Impersonator Who’s the Real Deal
results.summary_short: “The Identical” portrays a man who is unaware that he was separated from his twin as a baby and makes a career of imitating his famous brother’s act.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Identical

results.headline: A Princess Bride in a Digital Forever
results.summary_short: Ari Folman’s allegorical movie “The Congress” stars Robin Wright as a midcareer actress named Robin Wright, whom a studio wants to digitize for posterity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Congress

results.headline: For a ‘Don Giovanni’ Fan, a Hedonism Driven by Fear
results.summary_short: In “Naked Opera,” a man of mysterious means spends his cash on performances of “Don Giovanni” across Europe and on a steady succession of what appear to be male escorts.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Naked Opera

results.headline: A Singer of Soul Goes in Search of His Own
results.summary_short: Tim Sutton’s “Memphis” follows a blocked songwriter (Willis Earl Beal) as he struggles to rediscover his muse.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Memphis

results.display_title: Thunder and the House of Magic
results.headline: Puss Battles Sourpuss Over Old Magician’s Fate
results.summary_short: In “Thunder and the House of Magic,” an abandoned cat lands in the eccentric home of an elderly magician, whose greedy nephew wants to sell it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thunder and the House of Magic

results.headline: Witnesses to the Collapse
results.summary_short: Rory Kennedy’s documentary “Last Days in Vietnam” examines the fall of Saigon and the evacuation of Americans and Vietnamese.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Days in Vietnam

results.headline: What the Monks Can Teach Us
results.summary_short: “The Rule,” by Marylou and Jerome Bongiorno, is about St. Benedict’s Prep, an urban school run by the monks of Newark Abbey.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rule

results.headline: Cornered, They Reach for Their Sex Pistols
results.summary_short: “Kelly & Cal,” starring Juliette Lewis, centers on a punk rocker turned bored suburban mother who takes up with a 17-year-old in a wheelchair.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kelly & Cal
